definition.formal: Cyanoacrylate venous closure is a non-thermal, non-tumescent endovenous ablation technique in which a medical-grade cyanoacrylate adhesive is delivered into an incompetent saphenous vein via catheter under ultrasound guidance, causing immediate mechanical closure followed by inflammatory obliteration.
definition.clinical: A method to seal varicose veins using a specialized 'superglue' that is injected inside the vein, causing immediate closure without the need for numbing injections along the entire vein.

core_concepts.explanation: N-butyl cyanoacrylate polymerizes on contact with blood or tissue, creating immediate mechanical closure. This triggers a foreign body inflammatory response leading to chronic fibrosis and permanent vein obliteration over weeks to months.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Unlike thermal ablation, closure is immediate and not dependent on heat generation. This eliminates the need for tumescent anesthesia.

core_concepts.explanation: No tumescent anesthesia is required because there is no heat. This reduces procedure time, eliminates multiple needle sticks, and allows treatment of the entire vein with a single needle puncture.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Improved patient comfort, shorter procedure times, and no risk of thermal nerve injury.

core_concepts.explanation: The adhesive is delivered through a specialized catheter system in 0.1 mL aliquots every 3 cm along the vein. External compression is applied for 3 minutes after each injection to ensure wall apposition.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Precise delivery technique ensures adequate adhesive distribution without excess material.

core_concepts.explanation: Ideal candidates have straight GSV segments with diameter 5-15 mm. May be less suitable for very tortuous veins where catheter advancement is difficult. No restriction for patients with cardiac shunts (no air or foam used).
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Unlike foam sclerotherapy, CAC is safe in patients with PFO. Unlike thermal ablation, no concern for nerve injury in lower leg.

core_concepts.explanation: Patients commonly experience mild phlebitis with tenderness and erythema along the treated vein at 1-2 weeks. This represents the expected inflammatory response to the cyanoacrylate and resolves with time.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Counsel patients that local tenderness and redness are expected and not concerning.

indications: Patients with contraindication to tumescent anesthesia

absolute: Acute superficial thrombophlebitis in target vein
relative: Severe tortuous vein preventing catheter passage

preparation: Single access site preparation (typically below knee or at knee)
procedure_steps: Insert introducer sheath into GSV below knee under ultrasound
Advance catheter to 5 cm from SFJ
Inject 0.1 mL adhesive, then apply compression for 3 minutes
Pull catheter 3 cm, inject, compress - repeat sequentially
Continue until entire vein treated to access site
post_procedure: No compression stockings required (though may be used)

outcomes.success_rates: Occlusion rates 97-99% at 1 year; 95% at 3 years
outcomes.comparison: Non-inferior to radiofrequency ablation in randomized trials
disadvantages: Higher material cost than thermal ablation

uncommon: Extension of adhesive into deep vein (rare, usually without sequelae)

learning_objectives: Explain the mechanism of action of cyanoacrylate closure
List the advantages of NTNT ablation techniques
Describe the delivery technique for CAC
Counsel patients on expected post-procedure findings
key_takeaways: Cyanoacrylate glue causes immediate mechanical closure + inflammatory fibrosis
No tumescent anesthesia = improved patient comfort
Phlebitis-like reaction at 1-2 weeks is expected and resolves
Excellent 1-3 year outcomes comparable to thermal ablation

primary_sources.citation: Morrison N, et al. Five-year extension study of patients from a randomized clinical trial (VeClose) comparing cyanoacrylate closure versus radiofrequency ablation for the treatment of incompetent great saphenous veins. J Vasc Surg Venous Lymphat Disord. 2020;8:978-989.

guidelines: SVS/AVF Clinical Practice Guidelines for Varicose Veins
